clusters.title: What is chickenpox and how can I get my child vaccinated?
clusters.neutral_headline: Chickenpox vaccination offered to children in England

items.title: What is chickenpox and how can I get my child vaccinated?
items.standfirst: The NHS in England and Wales will start offering the MMRV vaccine to young children from January 2026.
items.content: The NHS in England and Wales will start offering the MMRV vaccine to young children from January 2026.

items.title: Children to be offered chickenpox vaccine on NHS
items.standfirst: All young children in England and Wales will be offered a free chickenpox vaccine by the NHS from January 2026.
items.content: All young children in England and Wales will be offered a free chickenpox vaccine by the NHS from January 2026.

items.title: Why is chickenpox vaccination being offered to children in England next year?
items.standfirst: Free NHS vaccination is aimed at reducing hospital admissions and protecting those most at risk of complicationsFor the first time, a free chickenpox vaccination will be offered to children in England by the NHS from January next year. Here we explore the background to the rollout. Continue reading...
items.content: Free NHS vaccination is aimed at reducing hospital admissions and protecting those most at risk of complicationsFor the first time, a free chickenpox vaccination will be offered to children in England by the NHS from January next year. Here we explore the background to the rollout. Continue reading...

items.title: Chickenpox jabs introduced as experts warn many children in England start school without vaccinations
items.standfirst: Experts say country needs ‘wake-up call’, while NHS will offer childhood chickenpox jab for first timeWhy is chickenpox vaccination being offered on NHS?England needs to “wake up” to its faltering infant vaccination programme, experts have warned, as it was revealed that one in five children start primary school unprotected from serious infectious diseases.It comes as the government announces a new vaccination programme for chickenpox from January, meaning that GPs will offer eligible children a combined vaccine for measles, mumps, rubella and varicella – the clinical term for chickenpox – as part of the routine infant vaccination schedule. Continue reading...
items.content: Experts say country needs ‘wake-up call’, while NHS will offer childhood chickenpox jab for first timeWhy is chickenpox vaccination being offered on NHS?England needs to “wake up” to its faltering infant vaccination programme, experts have warned, as it was revealed that one in five children start primary school unprotected from serious infectious diseases.It comes as the government announces a new vaccination programme for chickenpox from January, meaning that GPs will offer eligible children a combined vaccine for measles, mumps, rubella and varicella – the clinical term for chickenpox – as part of the routine infant vaccination schedule. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The NHS in England will offer the chickenpox vaccine from January 2026.
The vaccine will be the MMRV vaccine for young children.
The free vaccination aims to reduce hospital admissions.
The vaccination program will protect those at risk of complications.
Experts warn of faltering infant vaccination programs in England.

clusters.title: RFK Jr continues to make dubious health claims as CDC roils under his leadership
clusters.neutral_headline: RFK Jr. Faces Criticism Regarding Health Claims and CDC

items.title: RFK Jr continues to make dubious health claims as CDC roils under his leadership
items.standfirst: As leaders at Centers for Disease Control quit after director’s firing, Kennedy stokes controversy with pet theoriesIn a week of chaos at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Donald Trump’s health secretary, Robert F Kennedy Jr, has continued to make questionable medical and health claims – and has been slammed for them by experts and lawmakers alike.In recent days, Kennedy has been facing increasing calls for his resignation following the Trump administration’s firing of the CDC director, Susan Monarez, which in turn prompted four other top officials to quit the agency. The chaos across US health agencies also comes as Kennedy released a slew of controversial and contradictory rules surrounding Covid-19 vaccines. Continue reading...
items.content: As leaders at Centers for Disease Control quit after director’s firing, Kennedy stokes controversy with pet theoriesIn a week of chaos at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Donald Trump’s health secretary, Robert F Kennedy Jr, has continued to make questionable medical and health claims – and has been slammed for them by experts and lawmakers alike.In recent days, Kennedy has been facing increasing calls for his resignation following the Trump administration’s firing of the CDC director, Susan Monarez, which in turn prompted four other top officials to quit the agency. The chaos across US health agencies also comes as Kennedy released a slew of controversial and contradictory rules surrounding Covid-19 vaccines. Continue reading...

items.title: White House picks Kennedy deputy Jim O’Neill to replace fired CDC chief
items.standfirst: Deputy health secretary chosen as agency’s interim director after firing of Susan MonarezWho’s who in the CDC crisis?The White House has chosen a deputy of Robert F Kennedy Jr to serve as the acting head of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), a decision that comes as the standoff over the firing of director Susan Monarez has deepened, with Monarez’s lawyers claiming she will not depart unless Donald Trump himself removes her.A White House official confirmed to the Guardian that Jim O’Neill, currently the deputy secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), had been selected to temporarily lead the public health agency, giving Kennedy an ally in his efforts to overhaul US vaccine policy. Continue reading...
items.content: Deputy health secretary chosen as agency’s interim director after firing of Susan MonarezWho’s who in the CDC crisis?The White House has chosen a deputy of Robert F Kennedy Jr to serve as the acting head of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), a decision that comes as the standoff over the firing of director Susan Monarez has deepened, with Monarez’s lawyers claiming she will not depart unless Donald Trump himself removes her.A White House official confirmed to the Guardian that Jim O’Neill, currently the deputy secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), had been selected to temporarily lead the public health agency, giving Kennedy an ally in his efforts to overhaul US vaccine policy. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Robert F Kennedy Jr. continues making controversial health claims, drawing criticism from experts.
Several CDC officials resigned following the firing of the CDC director, Susan Monarez.
The White House appointed Jim O'Neill as interim CDC head, a deputy of Kennedy.
Kennedy is reportedly seeking to overhaul US vaccine policy with his new ally.
The CDC crisis is unfolding amid controversy surrounding Covid-19 vaccines.

clusters.title: Potassium-rich diet may cut risk of heart failure by 24%, study suggests
clusters.neutral_headline: Potassium-Rich Diet May Lower Heart Failure Risk

items.title: Potassium-rich diet may cut risk of heart failure by 24%, study suggests
items.standfirst: Eating foods such as avocados, bananas and spinach linked to lower risk of heart conditions, hospitalisation or deathEating foods rich in potassium, such as avocados, bananas and spinach, could reduce your risk of heart conditions, hospitalisation and death by 24%, a study suggests.Previous research has shown that cutting out salt from meals can slash your risk of heart problems. Reducing the number of meals to which you add salt or ditching it altogether can make a huge difference to your heart health. Continue reading...
items.content: Eating foods such as avocados, bananas and spinach linked to lower risk of heart conditions, hospitalisation or deathEating foods rich in potassium, such as avocados, bananas and spinach, could reduce your risk of heart conditions, hospitalisation and death by 24%, a study suggests.Previous research has shown that cutting out salt from meals can slash your risk of heart problems. Reducing the number of meals to which you add salt or ditching it altogether can make a huge difference to your heart health. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A study suggests potassium-rich foods may reduce heart condition risk by 24%.
Foods like avocados, bananas, and spinach are linked to lower risk.
Previous research showed salt reduction can lower heart problem risk.
Reducing salt intake can significantly improve heart health.
The study highlights the importance of dietary choices for heart health.

clusters.title: Experience: I see the world through a layer of snow
clusters.neutral_headline: Experiencing Visual Snow Syndrome: A Personal Account

items.title: Experience: I see the world through a layer of snow
items.standfirst: My condition has a name – visual snow syndrome – and it could be with me for the rest of my lifeIt was in February of this year that I first noticed something wasn’t right. I was coming to the end of my maternity leave with my second child, and had recently retrained from being a wedding cake-maker to a food stylist, something I loved. As well as looking after two kids with my husband, Chris, I was picking up lots of work. I was probably juggling too much, but life was exciting.That week, I’d just finished a big job and was exhausted. I began to notice flashing lights in my vision. I assumed it was a migraine from overworking – I used to get them as a teenager – and didn’t think too much of it. Continue reading...
items.content: My condition has a name – visual snow syndrome – and it could be with me for the rest of my lifeIt was in February of this year that I first noticed something wasn’t right. I was coming to the end of my maternity leave with my second child, and had recently retrained from being a wedding cake-maker to a food stylist, something I loved. As well as looking after two kids with my husband, Chris, I was picking up lots of work. I was probably juggling too much, but life was exciting.That week, I’d just finished a big job and was exhausted. I began to notice flashing lights in my vision. I assumed it was a migraine from overworking – I used to get them as a teenager – and didn’t think too much of it. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The author noticed visual disturbances, including flashing lights, in February.
She initially attributed the symptoms to overwork and potential migraines.
The author was juggling work and childcare responsibilities at the time.
The condition was later diagnosed as visual snow syndrome.
The author is sharing her experience with the condition.

clusters.title: Older autistic people need more help after years of misdiagnosis, review finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Older Autistic People Need More Support, Review Finds

items.title: Older autistic people need more help after years of misdiagnosis, review finds
items.standfirst: Research estimates 90% of Britons over 50 with autism aren’t getting right treatment and face added difficultiesResearchers have called for better support for middle-aged and older autistic people after a review found that 90% of autistic people aged over 50 in Britain are either undiagnosed or misdiagnosed.Greater awareness of autism and improved assessments globally mean it is typically spotted in childhood today. But in past decades autistic people were often forced to navigate middle and old age without the support a diagnosis can unlock. Continue reading...
items.content: Research estimates 90% of Britons over 50 with autism aren’t getting right treatment and face added difficultiesResearchers have called for better support for middle-aged and older autistic people after a review found that 90% of autistic people aged over 50 in Britain are either undiagnosed or misdiagnosed.Greater awareness of autism and improved assessments globally mean it is typically spotted in childhood today. But in past decades autistic people were often forced to navigate middle and old age without the support a diagnosis can unlock. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A review found 90% of autistic people over 50 in Britain are undiagnosed or misdiagnosed.
Greater awareness of autism is leading to earlier diagnoses in childhood.
Older adults often lacked support due to delayed or absent diagnoses.
The research calls for improved support for middle-aged and older autistic individuals.
The study highlights the need for better assessment and treatment.

clusters.title: CDC officials who quit in protest lead call to ‘get politics out of public health’
clusters.neutral_headline: CDC Officials Protest, Call to Remove Politics from Health

items.title: CDC officials who quit in protest lead call to ‘get politics out of public health’
items.standfirst: Staffers gather in Atlanta to applaud senior leaders who resigned after CDC chief Susan Monarez was firedWho’s who in the CDC crisis?Senior CDC vaccine research and public health leaders who resigned in protest told hundreds of supporters across the street from the campus on Thursday that the Trump administration needs to “get politics out of public health”.The agency is reeling from the firing of the CDC chief, Susan Monarez, but Monarez, who was confirmed as CDC chief just a month ago, has refused to be removed. Three senior leaders – Debra Houry, Demetre Daskalakis and Daniel Jernigan – resigned shortly after in protest, citing the alleged spread of misinformation under the Trump administration and political interference in their work. The staffers cheered and applauded them at the event on Thursday. Continue reading...
items.content: Staffers gather in Atlanta to applaud senior leaders who resigned after CDC chief Susan Monarez was firedWho’s who in the CDC crisis?Senior CDC vaccine research and public health leaders who resigned in protest told hundreds of supporters across the street from the campus on Thursday that the Trump administration needs to “get politics out of public health”.The agency is reeling from the firing of the CDC chief, Susan Monarez, but Monarez, who was confirmed as CDC chief just a month ago, has refused to be removed. Three senior leaders – Debra Houry, Demetre Daskalakis and Daniel Jernigan – resigned shortly after in protest, citing the alleged spread of misinformation under the Trump administration and political interference in their work. The staffers cheered and applauded them at the event on Thursday. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Senior CDC officials resigned in protest of political interference.
The officials spoke out against the firing of CDC chief Susan Monarez.
The protesting officials called for removing politics from public health.
The event was held across the street from the CDC campus.
The officials cited misinformation and political interference as reasons.

Continue reading...

clusters.title: Swallowing correctly can save your life – are you doing it right?
clusters.neutral_headline: Swallowing Correctly Can Save Your Life

items.title: Swallowing correctly can save your life – are you doing it right?
items.standfirst: The natural movement may be different for everyone, and being mindful could help prevent, or resolve, dysphagiaShare your stories of caregiving for your parents with your siblingsPeople often assume swallowing is automatic and infallible, but I’ve learned it isn’t.When my daughter was two months old, she caught RSV and stopped gaining weight. When she tried to feed, she coughed and sputtered, sometimes arching her back. She was soon diagnosed with dysphagia – a swallowing disorder. Continue reading...
items.content: The natural movement may be different for everyone, and being mindful could help prevent, or resolve, dysphagiaShare your stories of caregiving for your parents with your siblingsPeople often assume swallowing is automatic and infallible, but I’ve learned it isn’t.When my daughter was two months old, she caught RSV and stopped gaining weight. When she tried to feed, she coughed and sputtered, sometimes arching her back. She was soon diagnosed with dysphagia – a swallowing disorder. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Swallowing is often assumed to be automatic and infallible.

The article emphasizes the importance of mindful swallowing.

clusters.title: Shingles jab may reduce risk of heart attack, pioneering research reveals
clusters.neutral_headline: Shingles Jab May Reduce Heart Attack Risk

items.title: Shingles jab may reduce risk of heart attack, pioneering research reveals
items.standfirst: First global systematic review finds vaccine associated with 18% lower risk of stroke or heart attack in adultsGetting the shingles vaccine could lower your risk of a heart attack or stroke by as much as 20%, according to the first study of its kind.Shingles is a common condition affecting millions worldwide that causes a painful rash and can lead to serious problems such as deafness, long-lasting pain and blindness. It is more likely to cause serious problems in older age groups. Continue reading...
items.content: First global systematic review finds vaccine associated with 18% lower risk of stroke or heart attack in adultsGetting the shingles vaccine could lower your risk of a heart attack or stroke by as much as 20%, according to the first study of its kind.Shingles is a common condition affecting millions worldwide that causes a painful rash and can lead to serious problems such as deafness, long-lasting pain and blindness. It is more likely to cause serious problems in older age groups. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A shingles vaccine may lower the risk of heart attack and stroke.
The study found an 18% lower risk of stroke or heart attack.
Shingles can cause a painful rash and serious complications.
The vaccine is associated with a lower risk of heart problems.
The study is the first global systematic review of its kind.

clusters.title: People in England: share your experiences accessing NHS dental services
clusters.neutral_headline: People in England: share your experiences accessing NHS dental services

items.title: People in England: share your experiences accessing NHS dental services
items.standfirst: We would like to hear people’s experiences accessing NHS dental treatment amid fears of ‘dental deserts’People living in deprived or rural communities are more likely to experience “dental deserts” with a lack of NHS dental services, according to analysis of NHS England data from the Local Government Association.For instance, Middlesborough, one of the most deprived local authorities in England, has just 10 NHS dental practices per 100,000 people, compared to Richmond upon Thames, among the least deprived, which has 28 per 100,000. Continue reading...
items.content: We would like to hear people’s experiences accessing NHS dental treatment amid fears of ‘dental deserts’People living in deprived or rural communities are more likely to experience “dental deserts” with a lack of NHS dental services, according to analysis of NHS England data from the Local Government Association.For instance, Middlesborough, one of the most deprived local authorities in England, has just 10 NHS dental practices per 100,000 people, compared to Richmond upon Thames, among the least deprived, which has 28 per 100,000. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article seeks experiences accessing NHS dental treatment.
There are concerns about "dental deserts" in some areas.
Deprived and rural communities may lack NHS dental services.
Middlesborough has fewer NHS dental practices per capita.
Richmond upon Thames has more NHS dental practices per capita.

clusters.title: Mounjaro maker pauses shipments of weight loss drug to UK
clusters.neutral_headline: Mounjaro maker pauses shipments of weight loss drug to UK

items.title: Mounjaro maker pauses shipments of weight loss drug to UK
items.standfirst: US firm Eli Lilly reportedly tells British wholesalers to stop taking orders as demand soars before September price riseThe manufacturer of the weight-loss drug Mounjaro has paused shipments to the UK before a significant price rise for the treatment next month.The US pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly is due to increase the UK list price of the drug by up to 170% from September amid a White House push to get drugmakers to raise medicine prices in Europe to allow for price cuts in the US. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.title: Humans inhale as much as 68,000 microplastic particles daily, study finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Humans Inhale Thousands of Microplastic Particles Daily

items.title: Humans inhale as much as 68,000 microplastic particles daily, study finds
items.standfirst: Particles are small enough to burrow into lungs, says report, with health impacts ‘more substantial than we realize’Every breath people take in their homes or car probably contains significant amounts of microplastics small enough to burrow deep into lungs, new peer-reviewed research finds, bringing into focus a little understood route of exposure and health threat.The study, published in the journal Plos One, estimates humans can inhale as much as 68,000 tiny plastic particles daily. Previous studies have identified larger pieces of airborne microplastics, but those are not as much of a health threat because they do not hang in the air as long, or move as deep into the pulmonary system. Continue reading...
items.content: Particles are small enough to burrow into lungs, says report, with health impacts ‘more substantial than we realize’Every breath people take in their homes or car probably contains significant amounts of microplastics small enough to burrow deep into lungs, new peer-reviewed research finds, bringing into focus a little understood route of exposure and health threat.The study, published in the journal Plos One, estimates humans can inhale as much as 68,000 tiny plastic particles daily. Previous studies have identified larger pieces of airborne microplastics, but those are not as much of a health threat because they do not hang in the air as long, or move as deep into the pulmonary system. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Humans may inhale up to 68,000 microplastic particles daily.
The particles are small enough to enter the lungs.
The study highlights a previously under-recognized exposure route.
Previous studies identified larger airborne microplastics.
The health impacts of microplastics are more substantial than realized.

Continue reading...

Health officials are warning of drug rationing.

items.content: Some five million children - over half of those in England - are living in homes at risk of overheating.

Research suggests that hot homes can negatively impact children's health and well-being.
Overheating can worsen existing conditions like asthma and eczema in children.

The study highlights the need for strategies to keep homes cool during heatwaves.
